form.longName: PhenX PX810401 - Lung Function Lung Volume
form.preferredDefinition: The American Thoracic Society (ATS) and the European Respiratory Society (ERS) Task Force recommendations for standardisation of the measurement of lung volume testing outline how to obtain measurement of functional residual capacity (FRC) using body plethysmography, nitrogen washout, helium dilution, and imaging techniques. In addition, this source contains details regarding the assessment of total lung capacity (TLC), vital capacity (VC), reserve volume (RV), expiratory reserve volume (ERV), and inspiratory capacity (IC). These recommendations for standardization of the measurement of lung volume testing are part of a series of recommendations by the ATS/ERS Task Force for the standardization of lung function testing, which can be found on the ATS website at [link[www.thoracic.org/statements/pulmonary-function.php|www.thoracic.org/statements/pulmonary-function.php]]. Detailed information regarding patient preparation is included in the general considerations document for lung function testing in this series.

headerInstruction.text: Lung Function Testing: Measurement of Lung Volume. The American Thoracic Society (ATS) and the European Respiratory Society (ERS) Task Force recommendations for standardisation of the measurement of lung volumes can be found here as well as on..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: Which of the following ways is the measurement for vital capacity taken? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_vc)

validValue.meaningText: inspiratory vital capacity (IVC) - measurement is performed in a relaxed manner without undue haste or deliberately holding back, from a position of full expiration to full inhalation
validValue.description: inspiratory vital capacity (IVC) - measurement is performed in a relaxed manner without undue haste or deliberately holding back, from a position of full expiration to full inhalation

validValue.meaningText: expiratory vital capacity (EVC) - measurement is similarly performed from a position of full inspiration to full expiration
validValue.description: expiratory vital capacity (EVC) - measurement is similarly performed from a position of full inspiration to full expiration

validValue.meaningText: forced vital capacity (FVC) - volume of gas that is exhaled during a forced expiration, starting from a position of full inspiration and ending at complete expiration
validValue.description: forced vital capacity (FVC) - volume of gas that is exhaled during a forced expiration, starting from a position of full inspiration and ending at complete expiration

question.questionText: Has the subject suffered from myocardial infarction within the last month? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_myocardial_infarction)

Does the subject suffer from any of the following conditions: chest or abdominal pain of any cause, oral or facial pain exacerbated by a mouthpiece, stress incontinence, dementia or confusional state? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_conditions)

Was the subject involved in any of the following activities? Smoke within at least 1 hour of testing, consuming alcohol within 4 hours of testing, performing vigorous exercise within 30 minutes of testing, wearing clothing that substantially restricts full chest and abdominal expansion, eating a large meal within 2 hours of testing (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_activities)
Which position will the subject be in for the duration of the test? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_position)
Which position will the subject be in for the duration of the test? Other (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_position_other)
What is the subject's age? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_age)
What is the subject's height? (without shoes, feet together) (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_height)
Does the subject suffer from any deformity of the thoracic cage, such as kyphoscoliosis? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_thoracic_deformity)
If so, what is the subject's arm span from fingertip to fingertip? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_arm_span)
Does the subject suffer from any handicap which prevents an accurate measurement from standing height or arm span length? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_otherhandicap)
If so, what is the subject's knee height? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_knee_height)
What is the subject's weight? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_weight)
What is the subject's body mass index? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_bmi)
Is the subject currently taking any medication that may alter lung function? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_medications)
If so, what type of medication is the subject taking? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_medications_type)
If so, when was the last time the drugs were administered? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_medications_lasttime)
Does the subject wear any denture or dental treatments that are loose and/or that may interfere with performance? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_denture)
What is the current ambient temperature? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_current_temperature)
What is the current barometric pressure? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_current_barometricpressure)
What is the current time? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_current_time)
Is the subject returning for repeat testing? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_return_testing)
If so, is the current test time within 2 hours of the previous test time? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_repeat_timerestriction)
If so, is the equipment and operator from the previous session the same? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_repeat_equipmenttester)
Is the planned order of lung function tests identical to previous tests? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_repeat_orderconserved)
Does the subject currently suffer from upper respiratory or any other contagious disease or illness? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_diseaseor_illness)
Does the subject show signs of limited ability to cooperate? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_abilityto_cooperate)

validValue.meaningText: Yes (skip to measurement of lung volumes using imaging techniques)
validValue.description: Yes (skip to measurement of lung volumes using imaging techniques)

question.questionText: Does the subject suffer from open oral sores or cuts? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subject_oralsores)

Has reusable equipment (such as mouthpieces, breathing tubes, valves and manifolds or any other equipment showing visible condensation from expired air) been disinfected/sterilized? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_equipment_reusable_components)

Since the previous subject, if a closedcircuit technique was used, were volumebased spirometers flushed with room air at least five times over the entire volume range? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_equipment_closed_circuit)

Since the previous subject, if an opencircuit technique was used and the subject only expires into the spirometer, was the portion of the circuit which rebreathing occurs properly decontaminated? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_equipment_opencircuit_replacement)

Since the previous subject, if an opencircuit technique was used, were volume and flowbased spirometers used without inspiration from the measuring system had their outhpieces replaced/sterilized? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_equipment_opencircuit_mouthpiece)
If the spirometer was disassembled and cleaned, was the device recalibrated? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_spirometer_recalibration)

For subjects with transmissible infectious diseases, were any of the following precautions taken? Reserving equipment for the sole purpose of testing infected patients, testing such patients at the end of the day to allow time for spirometer disassembly and disinfection, testing patients in their own rooms with adequate ventilation and appropriate protection for the technician (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_subjects_infected_precautions)

If inline filters are being used, does the measuring system meet the minimum recommendations for accuracy, precision (reproducibility), flow resistance, and back pressure with the filter installed? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_inline_filtered)

Do personnel have the sufficient education (2 years college education) and training to understand the fundamentals of the test, know the common signs of pulmonary disease, and be able to manage acquired pulmonary function data? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_personnel_qualifications)

For personnel directly involved in pulmonary function testing, do they have formal training emphasis in healthrelated sciences (such as nursing, medical assistant, respiratory therapy, etc)? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_personnel_formaltraining)

For personnel directly involved in pulmonary function testing, have they established competency in pulmonary function testing? (familiarity with theory and practical aspects of all commonly applied techniques, measurements, calibrations, hygiene, quality control, basic knowledge in lung physiology and pathology) (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_personnel_competency)

Has personnel completed training similar to the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH)approved spirometry program? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_personnel_trainingprogram)
Has personnel passed a written and practical examination in the presence of an experienced instructor? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_personnel_competencyexam)

If it has been more than 3 years since his/her last competency exam or if lung function standards have been recently updated, have personnel taken a spirometry refresher training course? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_personnel_refreshtraining)

Are personnel maintaining a notebook of recoreds including but not limited to: calibration procedures, testperformance procedures, calculations, criteria, reference values source, and action to be taken when 'panic' values are observed? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_personnel_notebookof_records)

Are there detailed statements and/or publications on the selection of references values and interpretation of lung function tests along with an assessment of the reliability of the data? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_personnel_notebook_detail)
Which method from lung volume measurement is being used? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_methodof_measurement)

validValue.meaningText: Functional residual capacity (FRC) measurement, expiratory reserve volume (ERV), slow inspiratory vital capacity (IVC) manuevers to calculate residual value (RV) and total lung capacity (TLC)
validValue.description: Functional residual capacity (FRC) measurement, expiratory reserve volume (ERV), slow inspiratory vital capacity (IVC) manuevers to calculate residual value (RV) and total lung capacity (TLC)

validValue.meaningText: Functional residual capacity (FRC) measurement, inspiratory capacity (IC) manuevers to get total lung capacity (TLC)
validValue.description: Functional residual capacity (FRC) measurement, inspiratory capacity (IC) manuevers to get total lung capacity (TLC)

question.questionText: If first method, what is the reported value for the functional residual capacity (mean of technically satisfactory FRC measurements)? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_firstmethod_frc)
If first method, what is the reported value for the (technically satisfactory) expiratory reserve volume (ERV)? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_firstmethod_erv)
If first method, what is the reported value for the (technically satisfactory) inspiratory vital capacity (IVC)? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_firstmethod_ivc)
If second method, what is the reported value for the functional residual capacity (mean of technically satisfactory FRC measurements)? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_secondmethod_frc)
If second method, what is the reported value for the (technically satisfactory) expiratory reserve volume (ERV)? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_secondmethod_erv)
If second method, which approach is used to derive the value for vital capacity? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_secondmethod_vc)

If second method, and using the IVC/ERV approach, what is the reported value for the (technically satisfactory) inspiratory vital capacity (IVC)? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_secondmethod_approach_ivc)
If second method, and using the IVC/ERV approach, what is the largest measurement obtained for the vital capacity (VC)? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_secondmethod_approach_vc)

If second method, and using the slow EVC approach, what is the mean of technically satisfactory inspiratory capacity (IC) measurements? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_secondmethod_approach_ic)

If second method, what is the calculated value for total lung capacity (TLC)? (mean of three largest sums of technically acceptable FRC values and linked IC manuevers) (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_secondmethod_approach_tlc)
Which method is used for measuring forced residual capacity (FRC)? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_method_frc)
If body plethysmography method is used to measure FRC, which type of plethysmograph is used to track changes in thoracic volume? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_bodypleth_type)
If flow plethysmograph, what is the airflow rate in and out of the constantpressure chamber? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_bodypleth_constantpressure_airflow)
If body plethysmography method is used to measure FRC, is the transducer capable of measure mouth pressure greater than +/ 5kPa? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_bodypleth_transducer)

If body plethysmography method is used to measure FRC, does the measurement technique adhere to the following steps? 1) Equipment should be turned on and allowed an adequate time to warm up 2) Equipment is set up for testing, including calibration, according to manufacturer's instructions 3) Equipment is adjusted so that the patient can sit comfortably in the chamber and reach the mouthpiece without having to flex or extend the neck 4) Patient is seated comfortably with no need to remove dentures 5) The plethysmograph door is closed and time is allowed for the thermal transients to stabilize and the patient to relax 6) The patient is instructed to attach to the mouthpiece and breathe quietly until a stable endexpiratory level is achieved (usually 310 tidal breaths) 7) When the patient is at or near FRC, the shutter is closed at endexpiration for ~23 seconds and the patient is instructed to perform a series of gentle pants (~+/ kPa) at a frequency between 0.5 and 1.0 Hertz 8) A series of 35 technically satisfactory panting manuevers should be recorded 9) For those unable to perform appropriate panting manuevers, an alternative is to perform a rapid inspiratory manuever against the closed shutter 10) At least three FRC values that agree within 5% (i.e. difference between the highest and value divided by the mean less than = 0.05) should be obtained and mean value reported (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_bodypleth_measurement_technique)
If body plethysmography method is used to measure FRC, what is the reported FRC value? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_bodypleth_frc)

If body plethysmography method is used to measure FRC, was the mouth pressure transducer and plethysmograph signal calibrated within the past 24 hours? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_bodypleth_calibration)

If body plethysmography method is used to measure FRC, at least once a month or whenever plethysmographic errors are suspected, was the plethysmograph recalibrated with two reference subjects (biological controls)? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_bodypleth_calibration_controls)
If variablepressure plethysmograph, what is the pressure within the constantvolume chamber? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_bodypleth_constantvolume)
If volumedisplacement plethysmograph, what is the volume within the constantpressure chambler? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_bodypleth_constantpressure)

If nitrogen washout method is used to measure FRC, does the N2 analyzer have an inaccuracy less or = 0.2% of full range throughout the entire measuring range (080%), have a resolution of < = 0.01%, and have a 95% analyzer response time of < = 60 milliseconds to a 10% step change in nitrogen concentration? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_nitrogen_quality_control)

If nitrogen washout method is used to measure FRC, were pneumotachographs and other flowmeasuring devices calibrated within the last 24 hours by discharging a 3liter syringe at least 3 times giving a flow range of 06L/s? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_nitrogen_calibration)

If nitrogen washout method is used to measure FRC, for flow and nitrogen signals, does the system have a sampling rate of greater or = 40 samples/sec? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_nitrogen_samplingrate)

If nitrogen washout method is used to measure FRC, does the breathing valve for switching the patient from breathing room air to pure oxygen have a dead space of less than 100mL for adults and less than 2mL/kg in smaller children? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_nitrogen_breathingvalve)

If nitrogen washout method is used to measure FRC, does the measurement technique adhere to the following steps? 1) Equipment is turned on and allowed an adequate warmup time, with calibration as instructed by manufacturer 2) Patient should be asked if he/she has a perforated eardrum (if so, earplug should be used) 3) Patient is seated comfortable with no need to remove dentures. The procedure is explained, emphasizing the need to avoid leaks around the mouthpiece during the washout and using a nose clip 4) Patient breathes on the mouthpieces for ~3060 seconds to become accustomed to the apparatus and to assure a stable endtidal expiratory level 5) when breathing is stable and consistent with the endtidal volume being at FRC, the patient is switched into the circuit so that 100% oxygen is inspired instead of room air 6) The nitrogen concentration is monitored during the washout. A change in inspired N2 of >1% or sudden large increases in expiratory N2 concentrations indicate a leak hence the test should be stopped and repeated after a 15minute period of breathing room air. The washout is considered to be complete when the N2 concentration is less than 1.5% for at least three successive breaths 8) At least one technically satisfactory measurement should be obtained. If additional washouts are performed, a waiting period of >= 15 minutes is recommended between trials. In patients with severe obstructive or bullous disease, the time between trials should be >= 1 hour. If more than one measurement of FRCN2 is made, the value reported for FRCN2 should be the mean of technically acceptable results that agree within 10%. If only one measurement of FRCN2 is made, caution should be used in the interpretation. (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_nitrogen_measurement_technique)

If nitrogen washout method is used to measure FRC, was the N2 analyzer tared to zero using 100% O2 and then exposed to room air to confirm calibration? The percentage of N2 for room air should be within 0.5% of the expected reading for room air (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_nitrogen_calibration_zero)

If nitrogen washout method is used to measure FRC, before initial use and once every 6 months thereafter, was the linearity of the N2 analyzer confirmed by measuring the N2 percentage of a calibration gas mixture, where the expected N2 concentration is ~40% and observed values are within 0.5% of the expected concentration? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_nitrogen_recalibration)

If nitrogen washout method is used to measure FRC, before use, was the accuracy of the flow and volume output measured by the device confirmed within the past 24 hours with a calibrating syringe? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_nitrogen_calibration_day)

If nitrogen washout method is used to measure FRC, was the performance of the device tested with biological controls at least once in the past month? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_nitrogen_calibration_controls)

If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, is the capacity of the spirometer at least 7 liters and is the device equipped with a mixing fan, CO2 absorber, O2 and helium supply, a gas inlet and outlet, and a water vapour absorber in the line to the helium analyzer? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_spirometer_qualitycontrol)

If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, before measurements are taken, was enough 100% helium added to the system where the helium reading was ~10%? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_calibrationstep)
If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, does the device have a flow of ~50 L/min? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_flow)
If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, what type of analyzer is being used? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_analyzer_type)
If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, what type of analyzer is being used? Other (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_analyzer_typeother)

If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, does the helium analyzer have a range of ~010% helium, a resolution of less or = 0.01% helium over the entire range, and a 95% response time of less than 15seconds to a 2% step change in helium concentration? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_analyzer_range)

If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, is the meter stable with a drift of less or = 0.02% for measurement periods up to 10 minutes? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_analyzer_stability)

If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, for systems in which O2 concentration changes substantially, was the helium analyzer recalibrated over the range of O2 concentrations encountered? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_oxygen_recalibration)
If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, does the helium analyzer allow a flow of >=200 mL/min? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_analyzer_flow)
If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, is the breathingcircuit CO2 levels during testing below 0.5%? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_carbondioxide)
If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, what is the temperature of the gas in the breathing circuit? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_temperature)

If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, does the temperature sensor have an accuracy of better than 0.5 degrees Celsius over the range of 1230 degrees Celsius and have a 90% response time of less than 30 seconds to a 5 degree Celsius step change of temperature of the gas inside the breathing circuit? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_temperature_sensor)
If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, does the breathing valve and mouthpiece have a combined dead space less than 100mL? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_deadspace)

If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, does the measurement technique adhere to the following steps? 1) Equipment is turned on and allowed an adequate warm-up time, with calibration as instructed by manufacturer; 2) The equipment should be set up for testing, including calibration, according to manufacturer's instructions; 3) Patient should be asked if he/she has a perforated eardrum (if so, earplug should be used); 4) Patient is seated comfortable with no need to remove dentures. The procedure is explained, emphasizing the need to avoid leaks around the mouthpiece during the washout and using a nose clip; 5) The patient breathes for ~30-60 seconds on the mouthpiece to become accustomed to the apparatus and to ensure a stable end-tidal expiratory level; 6) The patient is turned 'in' (i.e. connected to the test gas) at the end of a normal tidal expiration; 7) The patient is instructed to breathe regular tidal breathes; 8) The O2 flow is adjusted to compensate for O2 consumption (significant errors in the calculation of FRC can result in O2 consumption is not adequately accounted for); 9) The helium concentration is noted ever 15s; 10) Helium equilibration is considered to be complete when the change in helium concentration is less than 0.02% for 30 seconds. The test rarely exceeds 10 minutes, even in patients with severe gas-exchange abnormalities; 11) Once the helium equilibration is complete, the patient is turned 'out' (i.e. disconnected from the test gas) of the system; 12) At least one technically satisfactory measurement should be obtained. Due to extra costs and time in making multiple measurements, and the relatively good inter-day variability in adults, two or more measurements of FRC need to be made only when necessitated by clinical or research need. For younger children, it is recommeneded that at least two technically satisfactory measurements of FRC to be carried out. (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_measurement_technique)

If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, before the subject was tested, were the following items checked? Water level of watersealed spirometer status of all CO2 and water absorbers operation of the circuit fan baseline stability of helium and volume signals (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_quality_control)

If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, for systems that can be pressurized, were leaks checked for at least once in the past 24 hours and/or after every tubing or canister changes? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_leak_check)

If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, was the stability (less than 0.02% drift in 10 min) and temperature of the helium meter checked at least once in the past week? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_stability_temperature)
If helium dilution method is used to measure FRC, was testing of biological controls performed at least once in the past month? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_helium_calibration_control)
If the subject has limited ability to cooperate, which imaging technique method will be used to measure his/her lung volume? (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_imaging_technique)
If the subject has limited ability to cooperate, which imaging technique method will be used to measure his/her lung volume? Other (standardisation_lungvolumemeasurement_imaging_technique_other)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The American Thoracic Society (ATS) and the European Respiratory Society (ERS) Task Force recommendations for standardisation of the measurement of lung volume testing outline how to obtain measurement of functional residual capacity (FRC) using body plethysmography, nitrogen washout, helium dilution, and imaging techniques. In addition, this source contains details regarding the assessment of total lung capacity (TLC), vital capacity (VC), reserve volume (RV), expiratory reserve volume (ERV), and inspiratory capacity (IC). These recommendations for standardization of the measurement of lung volume testing are part of a series of recommendations by the ATS/ERS Task Force for the standardization of lung function testing, which can be found on the ATS website at [link[www.thoracic.org/statements/pulmonary-function.php|www.thoracic.org/statements/pulmonary-function.php]]. Detailed information regarding patient preparation is included in the general considerations document for lung function testing in this series.

form.longName: PhenX PX810501 - Nterminal Probrain Natriuretic Peptide Ntprobnp
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol provides instructions for drawing, processing, and storing blood according to the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) methods. Because there are many comparable assays for ascertaining levels of N-terminal-pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP), the protocol also provides basic guidelines to aid comparability among different studies.

headerInstruction.text: Summary of the Nterminal Probrain Natriuretic Peptide (NTproBNP) Assay. The following is a summary version of the full National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 20112012 protocol.Exclusion Criteria:Persons will be excluded from this com..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: Do you have hemophilia? (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_hemophilia)
If the SP answers "Yes," the SP is excluded from the blood draw. If SP answers "No" or "Don't Know," blood is drawn from the SP. (blood_draw_810501)
Have you received cancer chemotherapy in the past four weeks or do you anticipate such therapy in the next four week? (chemo_810501)
If the SP answers "Yes," the SP is excluded from the blood draw. If SP answers "No" or "Don't Know," blood is drawn from the SP. (chemo_blooddraw_810501)
Age (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_age)
Repeatability of the NTproBNP assay (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_assay_repeatability)
Record the results of the blood draw. (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_blood_draw_results)
Record reasons for a tube not being drawn according to the protocol. (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_blood_draw_tube_deviation)
Have you received cancer chemotherapy in the past four weeks or do you anticipate such therapy in the next four weeks? (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_chemotheraphy_4weeks)
Coefficients of variation of the NTproBNP assay (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_coefficients_variation_assay)
NTproBNP concentration (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_concentration)
Make of the equipment used to perform the NTproBNP assay (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_equipment_make)
Manufacturer of the equipment used to perform the NTproBNP assay (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_equipment_manufacturer)
If plasma is hemolyzed, turbid, lipemic, or iteric, then describe. (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_plamsa_description)
Determine if the plasma is hemolyzed, turbid, lipemic, or icteric. (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_plamsa_determination)
Record any comments about the venipuncture. (nterminalprobrainnatriureticpeptide_ntprobnp_venipuncture_comments)

Venipuncture Procedures: Editor's Note: Please review chapter 4 of the Laboratory Procedures Manual from the 20112012 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) for a full description of phlebotomy procedures. This manual is posted here, and is also available at the NHANES website: 20112012 NHANES Laboratory Procedures Manual. Venipuncture should generally be performed using the median cubital, cephalic, or basilic veins in the left arm unless this arm is unsuitable. If the veins in the left arm are unsuitable, look for suitable veins on the right arm. If the veins in the antecubital space on both arms are not suitable, then look for veins in the forearm or dorsal side of the hand on the left arm/hand and then the right arm/hand. Recording the Results of the Venipuncture Procedure: Immediately after completing the venipuncture, record the results of the blood draw, the reasons for a tube not being drawn according to the protocol, and any comments about the venipuncture. (venipuncture_810501)

Blood Processing: Please review chapter 8 of the Laboratory Procedures Manual from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 20112012 for a full description of blood processing procedures: 20112012 NHANES Laboratory Procedures Manual Centrifuge the tube at room temperature to separate the plasma and aliquot into an appropriate storage tube. Determine if the plasma is hemolyzed, turbid, lipemic, or icteric. If so, enter a comment to describe the plasma (blood_processing_810501)

Laboratory Assay for NTproBNP. NTproBNP can be measured using a twostep sandwich enzymelinked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) in streptavidincoated microtitre plates. The Sickle Cell Disease Cardiovascular, Pulmonary, and Renal Working Group notes that there are a number of different reagents and instruments that are appropriate to measure the concentration of NTproBNP. Once an assay is chosen for a particular study, the Working Group recommends that no changes in the protocol be made over the course of the study. To aid comparability, the Working Group recommends that the investigator record the make and manufacturer of equipment used and the repeatability and coefficients of variation for the assay. (lab_assay_810501)
Reference RangesAge Range (pg/mL) < 50 years old 300 4505075 years old 300 900>75 years old 300 1800 (ranges_810501)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol provides instructions for drawing, processing, and storing blood according to the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) methods. Because there are many comparable assays for ascertaining levels of N-terminal-pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP), the protocol also provides basic guidelines to aid comparability among different studies.

form.preferredDefinition: This protocol provides instructions for drawing, processing, and storing blood according to the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) methods. Because there are many comparable assays for measuring lactate dehydrogenase, the protocol also provides basic guidelines to aid comparability among different studies.

headerInstruction.text: The following is a summary version of the full National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 20112012 protocol.Exclusion Criteria:Persons will be excluded from this component if they: Report that they have hemophilia or Report that they ha..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: Do you have hemophilia? (lactate_dehydrogenase_hemophilia)
If the SP answers "Yes," the SP is excluded from the blood draw. If SP answers "No" or "Don't Know," blood is drawn from the SP (hemo_811001)
Have you received cancer chemotherapy in the past four weeks or do you anticipate such therapy in the next four weeks? (lactate_dehydrogenase_chemotheraphy_4weeks)
If the SP answers "Yes," the SP is excluded from the blood draw. If SP answers "No" or "Don't Know," blood is drawn from the SP (chemo_811001)
Age (lactate_dehydrogenase_age)
Repeatability of the lactate dehydrogenase assay. (lactate_dehydrogenase_assay_repeatability)
Record the results of the blood draw. (lactate_dehydrogenase_blood_draw_results)
Record reasons for a tube not being drawn according to the protocol. (lactate_dehydrogenase_blood_drawtube_deviation)
Coefficients of variation of the lactate dehydrogenase assay. (lactate_dehydrogenase_coefficients_variation_assay)
Lactate dehydrogenase level (lactate_dehydrogenase_concentration)
Make of the equipment used to perform the lactate dehydrogenase assay. (lactate_dehydrogenase_equipment_make)
Manufacturer of the equipment used to perform the lactate dehydrogenase assay. (lactate_dehydrogenase_equipment_manufacturer)
If serum is hemolyzed, turbid, lipemic, or iteric, then describe. (lactate_dehydrogenase_serum_description)
Determine if the serum is hemolyzed, turbid, lipemic, or icteric. (lactate_dehydrogenase_serum_determination)
Record any comments about the venipuncture. (lactate_dehydrogenase_venipuncture_comments)

Venipuncture Procedures: Editor's Note: Please review chapter 4 of the Laboratory Procedures Manual from the 20112012 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) for a full description of phlebotomy procedures. This manual is posted here, and is also available at the NHANES website: 20112012 NHANES Laboratory Procedures ManualVenipuncture should generally be performed using the median cubital, cephalic, or basilic veins in the left arm unless this arm is unsuitable. If the veins in the left arm are unsuitable, look for suitable veins on the right arm. If the veins in the antecubital space on both arms are not suitable, then look for veins in the forearm or dorsal side of the hand on the left arm/hand and then the right arm/hand. Recording the Results of the Venipuncture Procedure: Immediately after completing the venipuncture, record the results of the blood draw, the reasons for a tube not being drawn according to the protocol, and any comments about the venipuncture. (venipuncture_811001)

Venipuncture Procedures: Editor's Note: Please review chapter 4 of the Laboratory Procedures Manual from the 20112012 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) for a full description of phlebotomy procedures. This manual is posted here, and is also available at the NHANES website: 20112012 NHANES Laboratory Procedures ManualVenipuncture should generally be performed using the median cubital, cephalic, or basilic veins in the left arm unless this arm is unsuitable. If the veins in the left arm are unsuitable, look for suitable veins on the right arm. If the veins in the antecubital space on both arms are not suitable, then look for veins in the forearm or dorsal side of the hand on the left arm/hand and then the right arm/hand. Recording the Results of the Venipuncture Procedure: Immediately after completing the venipuncture, record the results of the blood draw, the reasons for a tube not being drawn according to the protocol, and any comments about the venipuncture. (processing_811001)

Laboratory Assay for Lactate Dehydrogenase: The Sickle Cell Disease Cardiovascular, Pulmonary, and Renal Working Group notes that there are a number of different assays and instruments that are appropriate to measure the concentration of lactate dehydrogenase. Once an assay is chosen for a particular study, the Working Group recommends that no changes in the protocol be made over the course of the study. To aid comparability, the Working Group recommends that the investigator record the make and manufacturer of equipment used and the repeatability and coefficients of variation for the assay. (lab_assay_811001)
Reference Ranges for Lactate Dehydrogenase: Age (years) IU/L05 140304510 1422901015 115257>15 93198 (ranges_811001)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol provides instructions for drawing, processing, and storing blood according to the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) methods. Because there are many comparable assays for measuring lactate dehydrogenase, the protocol also provides basic guidelines to aid comparability among different studies.
